title: RBA backs borrowers over investors
text:
Treasurer Josh Frydenberg added to the attack on Friday, highlighting the fact that Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe had said the rate cuts were intended to push money into the hands of households so that it could be spent, thereby boosting the economy.

‘‘The major banks have decided to put their profits before their customers, and that’s not a good outcome for their customers or the economy,’’ Mr Frydenberg said.

The banks have passed on only 57 of the 75 basis point reduction in the cash rate this year, reducing the effectiveness of the central bank’s stimulus.

The big banks have cited the adverse consequences of ultra-low interest rates on their lending margins as the reason for not passing on the rate cuts in full. They said their actions were an attempt to manage the interests of borrowers, savers and shareholders who relied on their dividends for income.

Analysts have said bank profits would be hurt by falling interest rates, with each 25 basis point reduction shaving about 5 per cent off bank profits.

Net interest income

Analysis by Evans & Partners suggested the annual net interest income of Australia’s big banks would fall by $8.2 billion if interest rates were to remain low for an extended period.

The fall in interest income, they said, would lower the return on equity of the banks and threaten the sustainability of bank dividends, which have become highly coveted as interest rates have fallen.

Advertisement

The RBA acknowledged that the fall in official interest rates would crimp bank profits. This is because an increasing proportion of deposits already pay close to zero interest rates, which cannot be reduced further in line with low rates.

But it said Australia’s banks were far better placed than their foreign peers to withstand the profit hit from ultra-low rates.

‘‘Most deposits in Australia currently receive interest well in excess of zero, so the extent of pressure on margins from these deposits will be smaller than in many other countries.’’

Mr Frydenberg said it was ‘‘disappointing’’ that the big four banks had not passed on the RBA’s 25 basis point cut in full.

He said funding costs for the banks were at historic low levels and customers could ‘‘vote with their feet’’.

‘‘We encourage people to shop around and get the best possible deal.’’

Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese called on the government to ‘‘exert leverage over the big banks’’ by imposing sanctions to encourage them to ‘‘do the right thing’’.

'Doing the wrong thing'

Advertisement

‘‘We also have the case that the government could simply, instead of just advertising things to advance its political interests, how about they spend a bit of that advertising dollar on actually saying to the big four banks that they’re doing the wrong thing, and enhancing the reputation of those smaller financial institutions that have passed on the full amount.’’

The Financial Stability Review, published every six months, seeks to identify risks posed to the Australian financial system, such as external shocks, household debt levels and changing economic conditions.

The report is the first since the shock May election result that sparked a recovery in the housing market. Risks from falling house prices had reduced, the RBA said, but ‘‘still exist’’ due to high vacancy rates and the potential for an oversupply of apartments in Sydney.

‘‘The cuts to the cash rate, and the resulting reductions in borrowing rates, have contributed to a turnaround in some established housing markets.’’

A change in lending standards, the Reserve Bank said, had led to an improvement in the asset quality of the banks.

It said it was important that banks were not overly cautious.

‘‘Lending always entails a degree of risk but excessive risk aversion by financial institutions can curtail the provision of credit that facilitates economic growth.’’
description: The Reserve Bank has endorsed the health of the big four banks, ruling out a European style profit squeeze from ultra-low interest rates.
